Award.AwardTitle: SUNY LSAMP 2016 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Cohort 5 at Stony Brook University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations to successfully complete high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. The LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (LSAMP-BD) activity provides two-year support at the postbaccalaurate level for students from historically underrepresented minority populations to matriculate in STEM graduate programs with the ultimate goal of earning a doctoral degree in a STEM discipline. Participants are selected from LSAMP institutions nationwide. The State University of New York System Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (SUNY LSAMP) at Stony Brook University is the host site for the 2016-2018 BD program in which a cohort of twelve LSAMP certified students selected from the national pool will engage in STEM research, academics and professional development activities leading to STEM Master's and Doctoral degree completion. The BD program at Stony Brook University provides a comprehensive set of support services that monitors student progress, builds a strong BD community, and increases BD students' academic and professional skills.

Ten cohorts of students have matriculated in SUNY LSAMP graduate LSAMP-BD programs at Stony Brook, Buffalo, Binghamton and Albany since 2006. The programs promote systemic change in graduate education practices and policy in ways that increase the success of individual students on the doctoral pathway and the effectiveness of STEM graduate programs, continuing the goal of diversifying America's STEM workforce. The program at Stony Brook University will be externally evaluated and students will be tracked throughout the program and into STEM careers following completion of STEM doctoral degree programs. Collaborations with other STEM networks and resources internal and external to the state as well as other graduate programs, such as NSF's Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP), Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP-T) and institutional resources will further ensure that students complete the STEM terminal degree.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the SUNY LSAMP 2016 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Cohort 5 at Stony Brook University Program was to increase the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students (African American, Hispanic, American Indian, Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander) admitted into science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) doctoral graduate programs. The SUNY LSAMP 2016 BD Cohort 5 at Stony Brook University Program successfully recruited 13 BD Fellows, selected from a pool of 19 applicants from 10 LSAMP undergraduate institutions. Fellows were admitted into nine graduate programs: Biomedical Engineering; Ecology and Evolution; Electrical Engineering; Genetics; Integrative Neuroscience; Molecular and Cellular Biology; Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology; Neuroscience; and Technological Systems Management.

BD Fellows have published in various journals and electronic archives, including eNeuro; the Handbook of Experimental Pharmacology; Nature Chemical Biology; and Nature Microbiology.

 BD Fellows have presented their research at various conferences, including the Computational and Systems Neuroscience (COSYNE); the European Signal Processing Conference; the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR); the Society for Neuroscience (SfN) Annual Conference; and the Pavlovian Society Conference.

 Eight of the 13 BD Fellows are currently enrolled in doctoral programs at Stony Brook University. Four of the BD Fellows have obtained their master's degrees. NSF SUNY LSAMP 2016 BD Fellows received several presitfious fellowships and awards, including the Dr. W. Burghardt Turner Fellowship (3 recipients); the IMSD-MERGE Fellowship (2 recipients). ; the Science Training and Research to Inform Decisions (STRIDE) Fellowship; the Stony Brook University Biopsychology Founders Endowed Fellowship in Psychology; the Ferguson Merit Award; and the  Stony Brook University Biopsychology Founders Award for Research (Integrative Neuroscience) in Psychology.

In addition to the financial support provided, the BD Program provided academic and professional development services to ensure that BD Fellows complete their master's degree coursework and transition into doctoral programs. The services and activities offered to BD Fellows reflect a multi-faceted, evidence based approach to promote student success through:

  • Academic enrichment activities: supplemental instruction  and writing boot camp;
  • Professional development opportunities: Research Cafeseminar series, lunches with senior university leadership; and field pathway-specific (Academy, Industry, Public Service) networking and career preparation workshops;
  • Social support activities included: monthly BD Fellow meetings, participation in a peer-mentoring program, community building events.

SUNY LSAMP 2016 BD Cohort 5 at Stony Brook University Program has greatly contributed to the diversity of graduate education at the university by expanding the URM STEM graduate student community. The program has also contributed to systemic change in URM STEM graduate student recruitment and retention at Stony Brook in the following ways:

  • We have been able to establish strong relationships with diversity programs at Stony Brook and other LSAMP institutions and alliances
    • Stony Brook diversity programs include: the New York State Collegiate Science and Technology Entry Program (CSTEP); Educational Opportunity Program / Advancement on Individual Merit (EOP/AIM); the NIH Initiative for Maximizing Student Development: Maximizing Excellence in Research for Graduate Education (IMSD-MERGE); and the Women in Science & Engineering (WISE) program.
    • LSAMP institutions and alliances include: the SUNY LSAMP campuses, NYC LSAMP campuses, Garden State LSAMP campuses, Greater Philadelphia Region LSAMP, and the Puerto Rico LSAMP campuses.
    • We have been able to establish working relationships with many of the STEM Graduate Program Directors at Stony Brook to help identify students for the BD applicant pool, develop specialized academic plans for our BD Fellows, and monitor BD Fellow progress. STEM Graduate Program Directors and faculty have also been instrumental in helping us recruit at national and regional conferences. They have attended the following conferences to assist our recruitment efforts: the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Scientists (ABRCMS), the Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in STEM, the John Jay Graduate & Professional School Fair, the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) conference, and the Society for Neuroscience (SfN) conference.
    • The partnerships we have created with LSAMP alliances, as well as other institutions, have allowed us to share our best practices with other programs and administrators to advance our shared goal of increasing URM scholars at the highest levels of academia and the scientific workforce.
    • The SUNY LSAMP 2016 BD Cohort 5 at Stony Brook University Program has increased the number of URM students who are pursuing STEM doctoral degrees and has provided them with the resources necessary to enter the STEM labor pool successfully. This will contribute to a more diverse and robust STEM workforce, which will foster a diversity of perspectives in STEM fields, ultimately enhancing scientific inquiry and innovation.
